channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [SPR-2597] Spring 2.0 RC4 does not use the proper constructor for EHCache 1.2
item.description:
Per Costin's comment:
"the EhCacheFactoryBean has to be updated to support the latest releases of EhCache"

http://forum.springframework.org/showthread.php?p=77572#post77572

The existing EhCacheFactoryBean does work with 1.2.3 but it does not work with 1.1 which I originally had. Something between RC3 and RC4 broke the ability to use ehcache 1.1 and now Spring requires 1.2+.
item.summary: Spring 2.0 RC4 does not use the proper constructor for EHCache 1.2

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
This is deliberate and expected, actually; see the comments in RC4's EhCacheManagerFactoryBean javadoc.

We use independent CacheManager instances by default now, assuming that EHCache 1.2+ is available. If you want to run Spring 2.0 against EHCache 1.1, explicitly switch EhCacheManagerFactoryBean's "shared" flag to "true", which leads to use of a shared (singleton at the VM level) CacheManager again - which should also work against EHCache 1.1.

In general, I'd recommend to upgrade to EHCache 1.2, though. There shouldn't be any disadvantage in doing the upgrade.

Juergen

I get this same problem but when upgrading to using EhCache 1.2.3 jar I get this error in my logs.

2006-09-27 22:26:12,889 INFO - [main] org.springframework.cache.ehcache.EhCacheManagerFactoryBean - Initializing EHCache CacheManager
2006-09-27 22:26:13,060 WARN - [main] net.sf.ehcache.Cache - An API change between ehcache-1.1 and ehcache-1.2 results in the persistence path being set to java.io.tmp when the ehcache-1.1 constructor is used. Please change to the 1.2 constructor

The bean def that tries to create this is as follows:

<bean id="myCache" class="org.springframework.cache.ehcache.EhCacheFactoryBean">
<property name="cacheManager" ref="cacheManager"/>
<property name="cacheName" value="com.company.MyCacheableObject"/>
</bean>

Unless I am supposed to be doing something differently this looks like a problem in the Spring EhCacheFactoryBean's creation of Cache objects. Please advise.

Thanks,
-Xavier

Ah, I misunderstood: It seems to be EhCacheFactoryBean that causes the issue, not EhCacheManagerFactoryBean, and the actual problem is that we use the EHCache 1.1 Cache constructor rather than the newly introduced EHCache 1.2 one. This is of course a valid complaint; I have renamed this JIRA issue to reflect that.

Juergen

I've adapted our EhCacheFactoryBean to use EHCache 1.2's extended Cache constructor to avoid that EHCache warning. However, that means it is not compatible with any earlier EHCache versions anymore: Spring 2.0 users are recommended to upgrade to EHCache 1.2.3 or later.

Juergen

For give the newby-aspect of this question. Is there an easy work around to side-step this problem. For example, is there a bean that can be defined that essentially acts as a no-op? Until the issue is resolved, I would be thankful for any advice on an easy work-around (either posted here or sent to my personal email.)

Thanks.

-Phil
I just saw Juergen's update (posted about 40 minutes before my comment). It makes my previous question a moot point. Thank you for the fix, Juergen.

This should be available in public CVS in a few hours, and should make it into tomorrow morning's "nightly" snapshot at the latest.

Alternatively, feel free to take the current sources from CVS (once they're publically visible there) and patch your local Spring version accordingly.

Juergen
